King Football reigns supreme at
Keith's this week, where Richard
Arlen, supported by the greatest aggregation of gridiron stars to appear
on the talkie stage, charges through
seven reels of smashing drama in
the latest and finest of the pigskin
epics: The All American.
The All American team of 1931
plays in the production as a unit—
the first time such a thing has occurred in motion pictures. To anyone this show offers a grand evening's entertainment, and as for you
rabid football fans—don't miss it!

To The

EDITOP

an erroneous

ing a political faction not in favor at the
University ?", queried a contributor to
this paper's letter column, Tuesday, who
signed himself "Roosevelt Republican."
Our answer is: Need we favor the political party which the students favor?
No! Was the vote taken in the straw
ballot on October 20 indicative of the
true choice of the undergraduate body in
the forthcoming Presidential election?
No! Only 340 ballots were cast in the
poll taken at the assembly last Thursday
morning. Of that number 154 were cast
for Hoover and 147 for Roosevelt. The
official registration for the undergraduate
departments at Homewood is 927. Only
340 votes were cast in the straw poll—
a mere 36 per cent of the entire student
body in the College of Arts and Sciences,
School of Engineering, and School of
Business Economics.
Is that a true
cross-section of undergraduate opinion on
the Presidential election? No!
We do not retract our view that Hoover has proved himself a rather weak
President; one who has, in the era of
depression into which the nation was
thrown following the election of the Republican administration, deliberately misrepresented to the people of the United
States the actual gravity of the economic
condition of the country; and, while
crying that his heart has bled for the
common people, one who has done everything for the big business men and nothing for the suffering small business men.
The nation, if cannot be denied, needs
a new vision in the White House and a
man who will be able to do much toward
lifting the nation from its present state.
The Democrats, most certainly, can do
much toward achieving just that end.

Suggesting Amendment
(Continued from Page 1, Col. 5)
should three-fourths of the members of
the class be made to vote in order to
have a valid election the possibility of the
power-seeking fraternity men conducting a successful political campaign among
approximately 150 to 300, or more, students is slim. No combine will be able
to garner enough votes for its candidates
through merely vote pledges.
The passage of this amendment will insure cleaner, fairer, more intelligent voting. The student will realize the importance of class elections and of placing
men at the head of the classes who are
capable, interested in the welfare of the
class and University, efficient, and
straightforward. The undergraduate will
turn first to the consideration of the
qualifications of the nominees before voting for any candidate. "The News-Letter" pledges to publish facts about the
various nominees' activities on the campus and each presidential candidate's
statement as to what he intends to do
for the Class and University and his
vow that he is not supported by a combine.
IN addition to demanding the consideration of the amendment recommended

Red Cross — Join!

The real importance of enrolling college
students as members is not merely to
obtain memberships from among a particular group, but to spread p, knowledge
of the aims and objects of the Red Cross
and to arouse the lasting interest of the
young men and women who are soon to
become actors in the public life of their
communities.
The Red Cross now plays a prominent
part in the activities of pupils of the high
schools. Without intruding upon the regular curricula, it encourages a sense of
citizenship and, through an exchange of
correspondence with schools of the insular possessions and foreign nations, a
broader interest in knowledge. The introduction to Red Cross work thus received in the secondary schools is carried into the colleges, where the annual
Roll Cali offers an opportunity for becoming acquainted with the program of
the society.
As readers of news events, college students know that the Red Cross has been
active everywhere in the past year in promoting its general peace-time activities
and especially in relief work. It now
may be worth while to speak of the part
taken by Red Cross in alleviating misery
due to disasters and to economic causes.
In those communities which face unemployment problems, the local Red Cross
Chapter is either the center of relief or
is a leading ag'ency in the relief organization.
By Act of Congress, the Red Cross has
charge of the distribution of a total of
eighty-five million bushels of government
wheat to the needy, handling its conversion into flour and its shipping and distribution. Again by Federal law, it has
added cotton to the milling business to
satisfy clothing needs of the people in
want.
During the year the Red Cross responded to the call of 62 disasters. Chief
among these was the $2,266,000 relief
program in .six of the Northwestern
states, giving aid to 266,000 sufferers. The
Red Cross also handled the relief and
rehabilitation of 2,906 families suffering
from the March tornadoes in Alabama,
Georgia, Tennessee and Kentucky. Altogether, the Red Cross expended $3,597,000 in administering to the needs of
77,500 families who suffered from natural calamities.
In the relief of the unemployed, particularly in the mining areas and industrial
communities, the Red Cross gave free
seed for vegetable gardens to 300,000
families.
In considering this relief work, one
should not lose sight of the steady service
given by the Red Cross in other lines.
Among these services is the teaching of
first aid and life-saving, which has been
given at many colleges over the country
as a supplement to athletic work.
Let it be remembered that the Red
Cross annual Roll Call opens on Armis-

Making telephone equipment presents many
an interesting problem to the engineers of Western
Electric—manufacturer for the Bell System.
A case in point is the drying of telephone cable
before putting on the protective lead sheath. This
step is of utmost importance, for the tiny copper
wires cannot carry your voice properly unless their
paper insulation is thoroughly dried. To this end,
Western Electric engineers devised special drying
ovens in which the air is thirty times drier than
desert air!
The same ingenuity and thoroughness go into
every step of making cable, telephones, switchboards and many other kinds of telephone equipment. The dependable apparatus that results is
one reason why Bell System seryice is dependable.

To The

EDITOP

an erroneous

ing a political faction not in favor at the
University ?", queried a contributor to
this paper's letter column, Tuesday, who
signed himself "Roosevelt Republican."
Our answer is: Need we favor the political party which the students favor?
No! Was the vote taken in the straw
ballot on October 20 indicative of the
true choice of the undergraduate body in
the forthcoming Presidential election?
No! Only 340 ballots were cast in the
poll taken at the assembly last Thursday
morning. Of that number 154 were cast
for Hoover and 147 for Roosevelt. The
official registration for the undergraduate
departments at Homewood is 927. Only
340 votes were cast in the straw poll—
a mere 36 per cent of the entire student
body in the College of Arts and Sciences,
School of Engineering, and School of
Business Economics.
Is that a true
cross-section of undergraduate opinion on
the Presidential election? No!
We do not retract our view that Hoover has proved himself a rather weak
President; one who has, in the era of
depression into which the nation was
thrown following the election of the Republican administration, deliberately misrepresented to the people of the United
States the actual gravity of the economic
condition of the country; and, while
crying that his heart has bled for the
common people, one who has done everything for the big business men and nothing for the suffering small business men.
The nation, if cannot be denied, needs
a new vision in the White House and a
man who will be able to do much toward
lifting the nation from its present state.
The Democrats, most certainly, can do
much toward achieving just that end.

should three-fourths of the members of
the class be made to vote in order to
have a valid election the possibility of the
power-seeking fraternity men conducting a successful political campaign among
approximately 150 to 300, or more, students is slim. No combine will be able
to garner enough votes for its candidates
through merely vote pledges.
The passage of this amendment will insure cleaner, fairer, more intelligent voting. The student will realize the importance of class elections and of placing
men at the head of the classes who are
capable, interested in the welfare of the
class and University, efficient, and
straightforward. The undergraduate will
turn first to the consideration of the
qualifications of the nominees before voting for any candidate. "The News-Letter" pledges to publish facts about the
various nominees' activities on the campus and each presidential candidate's
statement as to what he intends to do
for the Class and University and his
vow that he is not supported by a combine.

Red Cross — Join!

The real importance of enrolling college
students as members is not merely to
obtain memberships from among a particular group, but to spread p, knowledge
of the aims and objects of the Red Cross
and to arouse the lasting interest of the
young men and women who are soon to
become actors in the public life of their
communities.
The Red Cross now plays a prominent
part in the activities of pupils of the high
schools. Without intruding upon the regular curricula, it encourages a sense of
citizenship and, through an exchange of
correspondence with schools of the insular possessions and foreign nations, a
broader interest in knowledge. The introduction to Red Cross work thus received in the secondary schools is carried into the colleges, where the annual
Roll Cali offers an opportunity for becoming acquainted with the program of
the society.
As readers of news events, college students know that the Red Cross has been
active everywhere in the past year in promoting its general peace-time activities
and especially in relief work. It now
may be worth while to speak of the part
taken by Red Cross in alleviating misery
due to disasters and to economic causes.
In those communities which face unemployment problems, the local Red Cross
Chapter is either the center of relief or
is a leading ag'ency in the relief organization.
By Act of Congress, the Red Cross has
charge of the distribution of a total of
eighty-five million bushels of government
wheat to the needy, handling its conversion into flour and its shipping and distribution. Again by Federal law, it has
added cotton to the milling business to
satisfy clothing needs of the people in
want.
During the year the Red Cross responded to the call of 62 disasters. Chief
among these was the $2,266,000 relief
program in .six of the Northwestern
states, giving aid to 266,000 sufferers. The
Red Cross also handled the relief and
rehabilitation of 2,906 families suffering
from the March tornadoes in Alabama,
Georgia, Tennessee and Kentucky. Altogether, the Red Cross expended $3,597,000 in administering to the needs of
77,500 families who suffered from natural calamities.
In the relief of the unemployed, particularly in the mining areas and industrial
communities, the Red Cross gave free
seed for vegetable gardens to 300,000
families.
In considering this relief work, one
should not lose sight of the steady service
given by the Red Cross in other lines.
Among these services is the teaching of
first aid and life-saving, which has been
given at many colleges over the country
as a supplement to athletic work.
Let it be remembered that the Red
Cross annual Roll Call opens on Armis-

Making telephone equipment presents many
an interesting problem to the engineers of Western
Electric—manufacturer for the Bell System.
A case in point is the drying of telephone cable
before putting on the protective lead sheath. This
step is of utmost importance, for the tiny copper
wires cannot carry your voice properly unless their
paper insulation is thoroughly dried. To this end,
Western Electric engineers devised special drying
ovens in which the air is thirty times drier than
desert air!
The same ingenuity and thoroughness go into
every step of making cable, telephones, switchboards and many other kinds of telephone equipment. The dependable apparatus that results is
one reason why Bell System seryice is dependable.
